Earlier this month, Kurdish rebels based in Northern Iraq crossed the border and killed 12 soldiers in Turkey.
The attack is part of a campaign that's decades old now, but it may have been the last straw.
Afterwards, Turkey's parliament approved a cross-border invasion and as many as 100,000 Turkish troops are now poised on the Iraqi frontier.
The U.S.
has urged patience from Turkey and put pressure on the Kurds who run northern Iraq to expel the rebels, an organization called the Kurdistan Workers Party, or by the initials, the PKK.
The group operates openly in parts of northern Iraq.
In a piece that ran on op-ed page of the Washington Post on Saturday, Henri Barkey argued that the Bush administration lost an opportunity to resolve these issues before they developed into a crisis.
If you've been to northern Iraq or if you have questions about the political, strategic and moral issues involved there, our number is 800-989-8255.
E-mail us talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Henri Barkey served on the State Department's policy planning staff from 1998 to 2000.
He now chairs the international relations department of Lehigh University in Pennsylvania.
He joins us today from a studio at member station WAMU here in Washington, D.C.
Nice of you to come in today.
Thank you.
And Turkey seems to be ready to go into Iraq after the PKK fighters.
But you're right that a massive retaliation would be a major misfortune for Turkey, Iraq and the United states.
Why?
Because it's a treachery to come in to northern Iraq en masse.
That is to say, they were to bring large numbers of troops, equipment, tanks, et cetera.
They will have to go across the Kurdish - Iraqi-Kurdish controlled territory, and most likely, this will create a clash between Iraqi Kurds and the Turks.

And since it is their territory, you can imagine that the Iraqi Kurds will inflict casualties and vice versa and this will probably draw Turkey into an incredible quagmire much like ours in Iraq at the moment.
That said, I don't think this is what the Turks are planning to do in terms of a large operation.
Maybe they might be satisfied with a smaller one.
Well, the PKK has its bases up in the mountains.
Of course, the Kurds of northern Iraq are quite familiar with those mountains.
They're their mountains - bases that they've operated in for years against Saddam Hussein and various other kinds of operations, too.
These are fairly remote isolated places.
Can't the Iraqi Kurds say, lay down your arms time to give it up, guys?
I think that's what ultimately will happen, but before the Iraqi Kurds can do that to - and send out to the PKK, they want some assurances from Turkey.
And what the problem has been is if you want a lack of communication between Ankara and the Iraqi Kurds.
The Ankara government and its military refuses to talk to the KRG, the Kurdish Regional Government because it doesn't recognize it.
Even though the United States, the Iraqi government and everybody else recognize the KRG, the Turks refuse to because they said that Iraqi constitution has not taken its final form.
I mean, that's the lame excuse.
But the new problem is that they worry that the Iraqi Kurds in northern Iraq will ultimately achieve a very robust federal status within Iraq or maybe even become independent.
And that's at the heart of the matter.
But as far as the Iraqi Kurds going after the PKK, what you said is correct.
This is a very remote territory.
They are not near any major settlement areas.
And the problem is that the Iraqi Kurds are not as powerful as people think.
First, half of their troops are now in the south in Baghdad, Diyala and Anbar provinces helping us with the surge.
And the Turkish army has been fighting the PKK for - as you said, in decades and the mighty Turkish army has not been able to defeat the PKK and it's unlikely that the Iraqi Kurds will do it.
What the Iraqi Kurds would like is for the Turks to come up not with an amnesty but some kind of an arrangement whereby some of the PKK fighters come down from the mountain and go back home.
This will reduce the number of PKK fighters and therefore, it will make it easier for the Iraqi Kurds to go after them.
As it stands now, it's very, very, very hard.
And part of the problem, you're talking about on the tactical level and the operational level.
But on the strategic level, the Kurds of northern Iraq agree with the broad goals of the PKK.
That it's a group that's a little maliced(ph), a little strange, but nevertheless, they want a Kurdish share.
They want about a quarter of Turkish territory to become a part of it -Kurdistan.
And basically the Kurds of northern Iraq agree with them.
